awd_titl_txt: Efficient Distribution Classification Tasks via Optimal Transport Embeddings
awd_abstract_narration:
Classification allows one to organize data based on similarities and can provide insight into underlying relationships in a large variety of fields, including cancer research, survey analysis, and image and text processing. As a result, the development of efficient algorithms for classification tasks is an important research area. One approach, machine learning,  has proved successful in classification tasks, but it is usually focused on data points in vector spaces. In many applications, however, instances of data are naturally interpreted as entire point clouds, or as distributions, and do not lie in a vector space. Furthermore, the high dimension of such datasets leads to theoretical and computational challenges. This project is devoted to the development of classification algorithms for high-dimensional datasets consisting of distributions, and will focus both on their theoretical analysis and computational efficiency. To this end, the principal investigator will use the framework of optimal transport, which provides a natural way of comparing distributions. Students will be involved and trained in interdisciplinary aspects of this project.

This project applies knowledge from computational optimal transport, such as linear embeddings and regularized optimization, and machine learning algorithms, to study classification tasks for datasets consisting of distributions. The main goal is to develop approximation methods with guaranteed error bounds that also allow for algorithmic insights and efficient implementation. Open problems on approximation power, computational feasibility, and numerical analysis will be addressed. Specifically, the project addresses four fundamental questions that arise in the field: (1) What are the types of distributions that can be classified with traditional machine learning techniques through linear embeddings, and how does the choice of a regularizer affect accuracy? (2) How well can the Wasserstein distance and Wasserstein barycenters be approximated through linear embeddings using Euclidean distances? (3) Under which conditions can we guarantee separability with simple classifiers in the embedding space for disjoint classes of distributions? (4) How can we tailor our framework to address various applications, such as classifying structures in audio or video segments?

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research project developed classification algorithms for high-dimensional datasets consisting of distributions. The main tool used was optimal transport theory. While machine learning is very effective at classifying data in vector spaces, in many applications data is interpreted as distributions or point-clouds, which presents theoretical and computational challenges. The project developed efficient algorithms with theoretical foundations to classify distributional data, and included student training as well as interdisciplinary applications.

Intellectual merit 

The project advanced classification techniques for distributional datasets through linearized optimal transport theory. This approach successfully addressed both supervised (labeled data) and unsupervised (unlabeled data) classification problems. Theoretical analysis confirmed its effectiveness, particularly when applied to distributions generated by elementary transformations including shifts, scalings, and shearings. The attached figure shows how the proposed linearized optimal transport method successfully classifies MNIST digits 7 and 9 under severe shearing. The MNIST images were interpreted as distributions over a pixel grid, and the algorithm is able to linearly classify the data (visualized by the line that separates the two classes).

Additionally, the PI analyzed a projection method to represent high-dimensional distributions as collections of one-dimensional distributions. While this approach may simplify the data representation, it significantly improved computational efficiency. Under conditions similar to the linearized optimal transport framework, the PI showed that this method demonstrated advantages when applied to data created through shifts, scalings, and shearings.

Further research demonstrated that linearized optimal transport is effective in dimensionality reduction algorithms. These algorithms, traditionally applied to vector space data, were adapted to handle distributional data through the development of the "LOT Wassmap" algorithm. This algorithm preserved critical information while significantly enhancing computational efficiency to reduce data dimension.

Broader impacts

The research extended beyond theoretical advancements to practical applications. Working with collaborators, the PI analyzed long-term dynamics of the p53 tumor suppressor gene, revealing how heterogeneity in DNA damage signaling manifests early in radiation response. These findings offer promising potential for predicting long-term outcomes.

Multiple graduate students contributed significantly to this research program, with several components forming the foundation of their doctoral dissertations and master's theses. They were involved in theoretical development, algorithm implementation, and experimental validation. The project also provided opportunities for undergraduate students, who gained experience in mathematical theory and computational methods.
